text: 13  And if that's her position, she and her ministers should say so openly.  Claiming that the policies in the Immigration White Paper will somehow make the UK and UK workers better off is not accurate, and not consistent with the Govt's own evidence.  / Ends
author: jameskirkup

text: 12  This is apparently what Theresa May thinks Britain voted for in the EU referendum in 2016. Even if she’s right (and polling evidence suggests she’s not) then she’s arguing that people who voted for Brexit voted to be poorer.
author: jameskirkup

text: 10,  Oh, and this policy will make the social care crisis worse too.  NHS England reckins 7% of social care workers are EEA nationals. White Paper would cut the inflow of EEA care workers by more than 90%.
author: jameskirkup

text: 9. 9.  Why? Why deliberately set out to make Britain poorer?   Par 6.41 of White Paper gives the game away. This is policy based on perception, not evidence.  This is the opposite of leadership.
author: jameskirkup

text: 8.  If adopted, the policies in the White Paper would give the UK net negative levels of work-related EEA migration for several years.  UK policy is literally to *send workers home*.
author: jameskirkup

text: 7.  (The MAC found that migration has a “positive impact on productivity”, albeit one that is hard to quantify.  The MAC also found “no evidence that migration has had a negative impact on the training of the UK-born workforce”.)

text: 6. This isn’t a surprise.  The Govt is doing this even though its own Migration Advisory Committee found migrants have ‘no or little’ impact on employment  of the UK-born workforce. Migration is not a ‘major determinate’ of the wages of UK-born workers.

text: So far at least, this Budget suggests Tory pragmatism isn’t quite dead yet.
author: jameskirkup

text: The Brexit endgame may well come down to a simple question of Conservative appetite: is the party still hungry enough to continue governing that most of its MPs will compromise on Brexit, or is fighting the cultural-ideological war of Leave vs Remain a greater priority?
author: jameskirkup

text: Put it another way: a Conservative Party that can applaud Phillip Hammond for this Budget might be more able to stomach some more of the compromises that will be needed to strike a Brexit deal with the EU.
author: jameskirkup

text: Perhaps in the last 24 hours some Conservatives have remembered that they like succeeding politically, that success often comes when the party is at least slightly united behind its leaders, and that success does sometimes entail some compromise on sacred principles.
author: jameskirkup

text:
It would have been unsurprising to hear Right-wing Tories grumbling that Hammond & May have abandoned any attempt to shrink the state. 
 Yet they did not do so, also yielding to those immediate political imperatives.
author: jameskirkup

text: But those are modest items compared to the giveaway on public services, esp NHS. There was even a new business tax on online platforms and -- big point this -- *the overall tax-take is heading for a record high*.
author: jameskirkup

text:
Instead he bowed to the immediate political pressure exerted by public opinion, Jeremy Corbyn, and Theresa May. 
 Nor was it the sort of Budget that the Conservative Right might have dreamed of. Yes, they got tax cuts for “their” people and more money for defence.
author: jameskirkup

text:
He really is quite dry +hawkish on public spending; his inclination would be to save at least some of the windfall , and maybe even to address some of those long-term issues. 
 Yet he did not do that.
author: jameskirkup

text:
And of course, another obv point: this is all a sideshow compared to Brexit. 
 Still, I do see some interesting and possibly even important bits of politics here. 
 This was not the sort of Budget that Hammond’s instincts or political preferences demanded.
author: jameskirkup

text: So the sight of Hammond being lauded by newspapers that previously damned him as a tone-deaf plodder should not necessarily be seen as a turning point in British politics.
author: jameskirkup

text: A cynic might say that when you’re spending a large chunk of public money on the NHS and tax cuts for middle and higher earners, it’s pretty easy to land a successful Budget with MPs, papers and voters.
author: jameskirkup

text: Instead, the priorities were more politically immediate because politics>economics, obv.
author: jameskirkup

text: Sadly not much of that extra money went on addressing the economy’s long-term problems: weak productivity, chronic under-investment by business, a messy and underfunded skills and training regime, and a dysfunctional housing market.
author: jameskirkup

text:
Thoughts on the Budget, Brexit, and the Conservative Party: 
 In the end, it was a very simple Budget. Circumstances contrived to give Phillip Hammond some extra money in the public finances, and he spent it all.
author: jameskirkup

text: We're encouraging business leaders and politicians to help dismantle cultural barriers that stop more men working part time.    @Commonswomequ has done good work here: https://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/women-and-equalities-committee/gender-pay-gap-evidence-check-forum/sharing-parental-leave/ …  Others need to follow that example.
author: jameskirkup

text: I've written about my experience of being a man working part-time here:
author: jameskirkup

text: 36% of fathers would accept lower pay to work less + see kids more.  But 97% of employed fathers work full-time.  It should be easier for men to work flexibly, not least because it would help women work more + reduce the "motherhood penalty".
author: jameskirkup

text: Median working week for women falls from 37 hours to 25 hours after having kids.  Men work *more* -- work-week rises from 38 hrs to 39 hrs.   Working longer can help men get promotions/earn more.  But also means less time with kids.
author: jameskirkup

text: Before becoming parents, the wage gap between men and women is 11 percentage points.  Three years after kids, wage gap rises to 25 points.   The decision for women to work part-time has long-term costs.
author: jameskirkup

text: 10 years after the birth of a first child, seven in ten (73%) of mothers and nine in ten (89%) of fathers are in work. Mothers predominantly work shorter hours, with six in ten (61%) employed on a part-time basis. By contrast, 97% of employed fathers work full-time.
author: jameskirkup

text: Of those at work ten years after their first child was born, first-time mothers earn 11% less per hour, 19% less per month and work 9% fewer hours per week than first-time fathers.
author: jameskirkup

text: The motherhood penalty: @SMFthinktank calculations show that 10 years after having kids, mothers earn 11% less per hour than fathers:   http://www.smf.co.uk/publications/back-track-parents-working-lives/ …
author: jameskirkup

text: In sum:  MPs and others told govt to amend/remove Equality Act single-sex exemptions. Govt considered doing so. Then govt ruled it out.  / ends
author: jameskirkup

text:
June 2018
Govt says:

“We are clear that we have no intention of amending the Equality Act 2010, the legislation that allows for single sex spaces.”
author: jameskirkup

text:
July 2017
Stonewall commits to “advocate for the removal” of EA provisions allowing sex-based discrimination. 

https://www.stonewall.org.uk/sites/default/files/stw-vision-for-change-2017.pdf …
author: jameskirkup

text:
July 2017
Govt promises GRA reform  “ as part of a broad consultation of the legal system that underpins gender transition.”
author: jameskirkup

text:
July 2016
Govt response to W&E Committee says: “we agree with the principle of this recommendation” on EA exemptions and seeks evidence for “future policy discussions” 

https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/535764/Government_Response_to_the_Women_and_Equalities_Committee_Report_on_Transgender_Equality.pdf …
author: jameskirkup

text:
Jan 2016
Women & Equalities Committee says EA should be amended so that 

“occupational requirements provision and / or the single-sex / separate services provision shall not apply”. 

https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201516/cmselect/cmwomeq/390/390.pdf …
author: jameskirkup

text:
August 2015
Stonewall submission to the Women & Equalities Select Committee says MPs should amend the EA to 
“remove exemptions, such as access to single-sex spaces”

https://www.stonewall.org.uk/women-and-equalities-select-committee-inquiry-transgender-equality …
author: jameskirkup

text: I offer these facts because some are claiming “there was never any question of removing/amending EA exceptions.”   Those claims are either mistaken or dishonest.
author: jameskirkup

text:
Some facts about the events that preceded the Government statement here that the coming consultation on the Gender Recognition Act will be narrowly drawn and not affect the Equality Act’s single sex exemptions. 

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/214118 …
author: jameskirkup

text: + /9 Lots of ppl pointing out: still huge issues around the way organisations are interpreting Equality Act exemptions. I agree & EHRC guidance will be v important. My narrow point in this thread is abt tone & frame of govt approach on GRA consultation; those are positive.
author: jameskirkup

text: 8/  Last thought: For the love of God will someone now please give @VictoriaPeckham a prize for her journalism on this? She has changed the terms of terms of the debate for the better.  @TheOrwellPrize judges please note.
author: jameskirkup

text: 7/ Will be very interesting to see what, if any, effect this has on Labour Party position/thinking on gender policy. Many of the factors that helped add nuance + balance to Govt position are also at play in Labour, albeit some of them even less visibly.
author: jameskirkup

text: 6/ Still a long way to go before gender debate is normal, civil and appropriately boring.  But this is possibly the most significant + positive political statement I've seen on this topic this year.
author: jameskirkup

text: 5/ Why the shift?  a) Women's groups like @fairplaywomen @Womans_Place_UK raising awareness b) @MumsnetTowers users c) Tory backbench unease (see Jacob Rees-Mogg) + reality of hung parliament d) private worries among several serving ministers e) good staff work by GEO
author: jameskirkup

text: 4/ Govt's public position has shifted quite a long way from autumn 2017 + now accepts complexity of the issue and reality of different groups distinct and potentially conflicting rights/interests.  This is a much better basis for good policymaking.
author: jameskirkup

text: 3/ Clear statement from govt that women's groups are recognised as stakeholders in this process. Govt accepts there are different perspectives + interests, and all deserve respect and a fair hearing.
author: jameskirkup

text: 2/ Clearest statement yet that consultation on (necessary) reform of the Gender Recognition Act will be limited to improving GRC issuance process.  Single-sex exemptions in Equality Act will remain unchanged.  Big win for feminists + others concerned about exemptions.
author: jameskirkup

text:
OBR's fiscal Brexit dividend in context.  Leaving frees up spending of £3bn in 2020/21, rising to £5.8bn in 2022/23. Or £57 million a week, rising to £110 million/week. 
On the other hand: worse productivity, higher rates, lower growth and £15bn pa in extra borrowing.
author: jameskirkup

text:
Regular reminder:  OBR's gloomy growth forecasts partly come from the fall in net immigration it expects. 
And OBR doesn't expect net immigration ever to be "tens of thousands" - if that promise was met, growth would be even lower. 
(OBR uses ONS central forecast: 165k by 2023)
author: jameskirkup

text: No disagreement with that. But wages are not only measure of status/esteem.  (Not that journalists, esp at BBC, need to be told that....)
author: jameskirkup

text: I would very much like to see that. X
author: jameskirkup

text: Fair points.  It was in quote marks as a crude way of indicating the broad concept of increasing status/recognition of non-HE people. Which I do think would a be Good Thing.
author: jameskirkup

text: Oh, well that completely disproves my point then. Game, set and match to you. Well played.
author: jameskirkup

text:
Of course they do, or at least they contribute to it. Status is abt far more than wages: best-respected jobs are not best-paid.
This is abt social standards + exemplars. Politicians + media can do much more to address the (unconscious?) notion that not going to HE = failure.
author: jameskirkup

text: How many Cabinet minsters want their kids to do an apprenticeship or a technical qualification? How many clever people on political twitter? “Parity of esteem” is decades-old cliche, always promised never delivered. But it’s still the right goal.
author: jameskirkup

text: This goes beyond policy to culture:  it’s about the message sent to people who don’t go to university about their worth and value. Right now, too many “people like us” regard more than half the country as having failed because they didn’t do what we did.
author: jameskirkup

text: Agree 100% with @MattChorley.  The way people with posh degrees (yes, me included) have dominated politics, policy & national conversation is harmful & stupid.  It is also the root cause of Brexit, yet v few in politics/media have even accepted that, let alone responded to it.
author: jameskirkup

text: cc @FraserNelson
author: jameskirkup

text: Oh, and not one of you has pointed out the typo in this tweet either... thanks.

text: Some people have said nice things about some stuff I wrote about gender. Don’t want to sound ungrateful but it’s underserved: @VictoriaPeckham & @helenlewis & other women said it all first. But I get praise and they got abuse.  Draw your own conclusions
author: jameskirkup

text: Hello. Thanks for tweet, and for introducing me to the word "spaff".  The sexism is real, awful and awkward;  positive reactions to my pieces make me feel like a fraud since I don't think I've said anything you + Janice T + others haven't already covered lots before.

text: Thank you. I can't stress enough: I don't have the answers to this stuff and would like to learn more about it. I wrote the piece because I tried to find out more and found it almost impossible to grasp the central points of the debate amid all the shouting.

text: For clarity, I’m not commenting on/justifying detail of story, phrases, headlines etc. That’s for others.  I’m talking about the legitimacy of the story, and my knowledge of the people responsible for it.
author: jameskirkup

text: 5 for all that this is a story about Remain groups, Nick’s column can equally be read as a warning to ERG Tories to keep quiet and back T May, or risk no Brexit. This is their primal fear and probably best way to ensure their compliance.
author: jameskirkup

text: 4 Yes it’s unusual for Nick to have a byline on the news story but not unusual for columnists to be source of news stories. Bylining him is arguably more honest than the common habit of columnists originating stories without clear attribution.
author: jameskirkup

text: Declarations: I was Telegraph journalist for 10yrs. I voted Remain. I like & respect Nick Timothy and @chrisevans1 even though we disagree about some things. Suggestions that either is in any way antisemitic or would intentionally promote antisemitism are baseless.
author: jameskirkup

text:
Thoughts on @NickJTimothy / Telegraph - Soros:  
1 Use of Soros as Jewish hate-figure by nasty regimes + politicians is horrible and should be named as such. 
2 That does not change the fact that reporting this story was in the public interest

text:
Interested in @SMFthinktank research on the costs of nationalising the water industry? Great. Now you have two choices:
